1. The Circumstances of Throwing Oneself into a Tiger's Den The Circumstances of Throwing Oneself into a Tiger's Den, Part One At that time, the World-Honored One, together with the great assembly, went to the great village of Panchala and, arriving in a certain forest, said to Ananda:

At that time, the World-Honored One touched the ground with his hand, and it shook in six ways. A seven-jeweled stupa emerged before them, and the World-Honored One rose and made obeisance, circumambulating to the right.
Ananda!
You should open the door of this stupa.
It was seen to be a seven-jeweled casket adorned with precious things.
Ananda!

It was seen to contain relics as white as conch shells.

At that time, the prince greatly aroused his courage, and with the power of his compassionate vows, he increased his resolve. Fearing that his two older brothers would create obstacles together, he asked to return to the palace first, while he would come later.

At that time, the great earth shook in six ways, like wind stirring water, surging and sinking, uneasy. The sun was not bright, as if obscured by Rahu. The sky rained various flowers and wonderful incense powder, falling all over the forest. The gods in the sky all praised together.

At that time, the queen's hair was disheveled and she rolled on the ground, like a fish out of water or a cow that has lost its calf. The two princes grieved and wailed, together collecting the remaining relics of the Bodhisattva's body and making offerings to them, placing them in a jeweled stupa.
